Math and Logic

False + False = True

Can a statement be true if all of its parts are false? Surprisingly, the answer is yes!

An implication, also known as an "if-then" statement, describes a particular dependency between two claims. For example, the following statement is an implication:

"If Tony goes to the movie, then Jane goes to the movie."

In the example above, we have two different statements inside the implication:

The premise: "Tony goes to the movie."
The conclusion: "Jane goes to the movie."

The implication doesn't tell us anything about whether or not each of these two statements is actually true. Rather, it tells us about a dependency between their respective truths. An if-then statement tells us that when the premise is true, it forces the conclusion to be true.

Because the movie implication involves two different statements (the premise and the conclusion), there are four possible combinations for their truth values.

Which of these combinations disproves the implication's claim? Think through these scenarios, and which of them (if any) would prove that the implication is false?

"If Tony goes to the movie, then Jane goes to the movie."

The implication claims that Tony's presence at the movie will necessarily result in Jane's presence; so, if Tony is at the movie and Jane is not, the implication was definitely false. However, the implication makes no claims about what Jane will do when Tony doesn't go to the movie, so what Jane does when Tony is elsewhere has no bearing on the implication's truth value. The only way for an implication to be false is if the premise is true but the conclusion is false.

When the premise of an implication is false (when Tony does not go to the movie), the implication is true, but it is said to be vacuously true. As another example, the statement, "if Earth is flat, then all elephants can speak fluent French," is logically true (at least in this universe). It is true but vacuously true because the premise that Earth is flat is false.

In our movie scenario, the vacuously true case is a bit less outlandish, but it still exemplifies the strange but logical result that an implication with a false premise and a false conclusion is itself a true statement. Consider this:

  • "If Tony goes to the movie, then Jane goes to the movie."
  • Tony must go to a family reunion instead of the movie.
  • Jane must go to a football game instead of the movie.

In this scenario, both the premise and conclusion of the first statement are false, but the implication itself is still true. This counter-intuitive property of implication and of vacuous truth is key to understanding many logic puzzles, including the one below.

Today's Challenge

On any given day, Sam either always lies or always tells the truth.

Today, Sam says:

  1. "I am exactly five feet tall."
  2. "If I am exactly five feet tall, then I also own a ham radio!"

Does Sam own a ham radio? \\[1em]

Note: Don't rely on the picture for this problem. Try to determine using logic what we can conclude from Sam's statements. \\[1.5em]

Yes No It's impossible to tell.

Gandoff Tan

Let ppp be the statement 'I am exactly five feet tall.'

Let qqq be the statement 'I own a ham radio.'

Then, (p  ⟹  q)(p\implies q)(p⟹q) is the statement 'If I am exactly five feet tall, then I also own a ham radio.'

The truth table for (p  ⟹  q)(p\implies q)(p⟹q):

pqp  ⟹  q⊤⊤⊤⊤⊥⊥⊥⊤⊤⊥⊥⊤\begin{array}{|cc|c|} \hline p&q&p\implies q\\ \hline \top&\top&\top\\ \top&\bot&\bot\\ \bot&\top&\top\\ \bot&\bot&\top\\ \hline \end{array}p⊤⊤⊥⊥​q⊤⊥⊤⊥​p⟹q⊤⊥⊤⊤​​

⊤\top⊤ means true and ⊥\bot⊥ means false.

Since Sam either always lies or always tells the truth on a particular day and Sam makes both statement ppp and (p  ⟹  q)(p\implies q)(p⟹q), ppp must match (p  ⟹  q)(p\implies q)(p⟹q).

Since only the first row shows that both ppp and (p  ⟹  q)(p\implies q)(p⟹q) are of the same state, in this case truth, only the first row satisfy this condition.

pqp  ⟹  q⊤⊤⊤\begin{array}{|cc|c|} \hline p&q&p\implies q\\ \hline \top&\top&\top\\ \hline \end{array}p⊤​q⊤​p⟹q⊤​​

Therefore, this implies that qqq is also true.

Kumudesh Ghosh

SIMPLE SOLUTION

CASE 1: SAM IS LYING

This means he is NOT 5 feet tall.

What this also means is that if he IS 5 feet tall, he does not have a radio.

But we know that he is NOT 5 feet tall. But then this is an impossible scenario that makes very little sense, he cannot be lying.

CASE 2: SAM IS TELLING THE TRUTH

This means he is 5 feet tall.

So, according to his second statement, he DOES own a radio.

Therefore, Sam owns a radio, whether he is lying or telling the truth.

Brandon Ahl
Jul 27, 2020

@Stef Smith – What you're saying you think is just not the rules of formal logic. When discussing formal logic, an anomaly that occurs is that sometimes arguments seem nonsensical in regular speech, even if they make perfect sense through logic.

The statement "if Sam is exactly five feet tall, them he owns a ham radio" is false only when both he is exactly five feet tall AND he does not own a ham radio. This is because the implication itself is proven incorrect. This is the only way a logical IF statement can be false. If he is not exactly five feet tall, the statement is immediately true based on the axioms we adopt while using formal logic. We don't concern ourselves with whether the statements are vacuously true or false.

Stef Smith
Jul 27, 2020

@Brandon Ahl – What I am saying is that there are things that Sam can say that are neither true nor false. If Sam, completely unprompted, says the word, “Butterscotch,” then that is not a statement that is true or false. Sam has neither lied nor told the truth. I think it’s reasonable that Sam be allowed to say “Butterscotch,” both on days when they tell the truth and days that they lie.

What I am saying is that a ‘vacuous truth’ is an unresolved expression that is neither true nor false. It does not become true simply because it is not false. And, as such, I believe that lying-Sam can say it, just as they can say the word, “Butterscotch.”

I don’t expect you to agree. You may take the opposite position that a ‘vacuous truth’ is a truth because it’s right there in the name. What I hope is that you see that should you believe that a ‘vacuous truth’ is an unresolved statement that is neither true nor false, that it logically follows from there that it cannot be determined if Sam has a radio.

There is some ambiguity here but the official answer is correct.

The ambiguity is in what it actually means for an implication to be a "lie": - Is the statement meaningless? - or the actual logical negation of A->B (i.e. A and not B)?

Shaun Tse
Jul 28, 2020

The heart of the problem lies with the condition that Sam is lying and statement two.

Lying in this case means that the statement is FALSE.

lets take a look at statement 2: "If I am exactly five feet tall, then I also own a ham radio."

The ONLY condition that makes this statement false is if Sam IS five feet tall AND does NOT own a ham radio.

And the kicker: If Sam is not five feet tall the second statement will NEVER be false! Think about it! If Sam is four feet tall (ham radio or not), is the second statement False?

Nope!

The fact is, if Sam is not exactly five feet tall, we don't care if he has a ham radio or not, because it will not be a lie.

Example: "If my name is Charlie, I will eat an apple today." This is not a lie! This will only be a lie if I change my name to Charlie and don't eat an apple today. Since my name is NOT Charlie, I am not telling a lie, apple or no apple.

And.... since Statement 2 can NOT be false (because of statement 1), Sam can't be lying!

Liam Robertson
Jul 27, 2020

The reason Sam owns the ham radio is because (according to the logic Brilliant gives us) Sam logically cannot lie.

Brilliant says that an implication is false (i.e. "a lie") if the premise is true but the conclusion is false. Therefore if "If I am exactly five feet tall, then I own a ham radio" is a lie, then Sam is five feet tall and doesn't own a ham radio. But we know he isn't five feet tall because of his first statement. Sam cannot simultaneously be five feet and not five feet. Therefore we have a contradiction and it is impossible for Sam to lie.

Does this really make sense though? I'm not sure. But this is the line of thought you need to have in order to answer this question.

alazrabed .
Jul 27, 2020

So, by definition, an implication statement can only be false if the premise is verified to be true. If the premise is false, then the implication statement is (vacuously) true. However absurd it is sounding. So for instance I could say:

If I was Plato in an anterior life, I was also Socrates in an anterior life.

Which is absurd, let alone the fact that Plato and Socrates were (quite probably) contemporary. But it is true. Vacuously. By definition.

Hence, in the case were Sam is lying with her first statement, she must tell the truth (vacuously) when uttering her second statement. But this is a contradiction regarding the assumption of the problem (either Sam is only lying today, or she is only telling the truth today).

Therefore Sam is telling the truth.

It's just a case of definition. It might be a bit underwhelming but that's all today challenge was about.

alazrabed .
Jul 27, 2020

@Stef Smith – I read "vacuously true" as "true until proven otherwise". With the assumption that all statements are true before they are asserted to be false. This isn't completely absurd. Statements that aren't implication statements can be, in the same moment that they are pronounced, asserted by an omniscient entity to be true or false. So being here and being there can't be true at the same time.

But if the premise of an implication statement isn't verified, even an omniscient entity couldn't assert that the statement is "definitely true" or "definitely false". In that kind of antechamber, I observe the convention to be that we say the statement is still "kind of true". Whether it is a judicious convention or not, I'm not in a position to judge. But I assume that it is a useful one.

I wrote a solution where I talk about that a little more. Cheers

Alazrabed .
Jul 27, 2020

Alright, let's get a magnifying glass on the concept "vacuous".

VVV aaa ccc uuu ooo uuu sss lll yyy

A vacuous statement is logically valid but cannot be shown to be untrue at the moment. In other words, it is yet to be qualified as "definitely true" or "definitely false". So, by default, we make the convention that it is

VVV aaa ccc uuu ooo uuu sss lll yyy

TTT rrr uuu eee

(almost apologizing for the over-dramatically bullying of incredulity, but not quite.)

So let's see this in action. Let's assume today Sam is telling the truth. Then she must always tell the truth.

I am exactly five feet tall.

If I am five feet tall, then I own a ham radio.

No problem there. She is five feet tall and she does own a ham radio.

But we're told some days she also lies, and does so necessarily, throughout the day. So if today she is lying, she is always lying. To be clear, all the statements that she pronounces on that day must be false. No bargaining, no discount. False. Not true. Not even vacuously true (here we go, oh no no no).

So let's assume she is lying. Again, both of her statements:

I am exactly five feet tall.

If I am five feet tall, then I own a ham radio.

There, she isn't five feet tall. Sure, no issue so far. But if she isn't five feet tall, then the premise of the second statement is false (that's almost tautological at this point). And if the premise is false, the whole statement cannot be verified to be neither "definitely true" nor "definitely false". And we said above that this correspond to the statement being

VVV aaa ccc uuu ooo uuu sss lll yyy

TTT rrr uuu eee

That's to say, not quite "definitely true", but still true nonetheless. This is probably a convention, an arbitrary rule. If it's not the case, I'm happy to be proven wrong. But because it is a convention, it has the same value as capitalizing the first letter of a sentence and putting a dot at the end of it. It's not absolutely true, but still usefully true in order to communicate coherently.

Anyways. From the assumption that Sam is lying today, we arrive at the conclusion that she is also telling the truth. This is a contraction. Therefore this can't happen. Therefore Sam is telling the truth (because there is only two possibilities, given the formulation of the problem). Therefore Sam is five feet tall. Therefore Sam does own a ham radio.

QQQEEEDDD

The "Brilliant logic" isn't wrong. Brilliant isn't confused. This is logic, period. Bertrand Russel would approve. Good day to you.

David Hairston
Jul 27, 2020

Statement 1 is absolute. Statement 2 is conditional, where the premise of statement 2 is statement 1. Both statements need to have the same True/False value.

If statement 1 is False then statement 2 is vacuously TRUE, which is a contradiction. Therefore, it can't happen.

If statement 1 is True then statement 2 must be True. Note that the premise of statement 2 (i.e. statement 1) is already True. The only way for statement 2 to be False (which it can't be) is if the conclusion is False.

Q.E.D.: the conclusion is True: Sam owns a ham radio.

@Thomas Raffill – Sam is short for Samantha ...

When Sam spoke, she was telling the truth, given the choice of things she was able to say.

When asked "How old are you?", the answer is understood to be imprecise to the moment but true to the interval in which it was spoken. Most people, I think, won't consider anyone a liar if they answered the age question broadly with just an enumeration of a year, despite the fact that such an answer is only accurate at precisely one moment.

The same holds for distance, area and volume, weight, and so on ... measurements. People aren't lying when they speak in these ways.

On the day of the challenge, Sam could not speak the two lies in the challenge because that was logically impossible and she was able to speak the two truths (given common understanding of what it means to be accurate truth). Sam is 5 feet tall and owns a ham radio.

" If the 1st statement is a lie, how would that force the 2nd statement to be true?"

The 1st statement is also the premise of the 2nd statement. Below is the quote from the introduction"

"When the premise of an implication is false (when Tony does not go to the movie), the implication is true, but it is said to be vacuously true. As another example, the statement, "if Earth is flat, then all elephants can speak fluent French," is logically true (at least in this universe). It is true but vacuously true because the premise that Earth is flat is false."

The If A then B\text{If }A\text{ then }BIf A then B sentences are false, when A is true and B is false. In other cases the sentences are true. So if I say that: If I’m the Santa Claus, then I will give you 5000$\text{If I'm the Santa Claus, then I will give you 5000\$}If I’m the Santa Claus, then I will give you 5000$ I won't lie if you don't get 5000$5000\$5000$, because I'm not the Santa Claus.

If Sam told the truth, then he has a radio. But if he lied, then he isn't five feet tall, so the second sentence should be true. But this is impossible. So he has a radio.

A table to If S then E\text{If }S\text{ then }EIf S then E sentences, where S is the statement and E is the effect:

SES  ⟹  ETrueTrueTrueTrueFalseFalseFalseTrueTrueFalseFalseTrue\begin{array}{|c|c|c|} \hline S&E&S\implies E\\ \hline \green{True}&\green{True}&\green{True}\\ \hline \green{True}&\red{False}&\red{False}\\ \hline \red{False}&\green{True}&\green{True}\\ \hline \red{False}&\red{False}&\green{True}\\ \hline \end{array}STrueTrueFalseFalse​ETrueFalseTrueFalse​S⟹ETrueFalseTrueTrue​​

In the possible cases SSS and S  ⟹  ES\implies ES⟹E are the same(both are true or false). We can see there is only one solution.

Liam Robertson
Jul 27, 2020

Hi Mahdi - the statement "If I am exactly five feet tall, then I don't own a ham radio" does not tell you anything about the situation where Sam is not five feet tall. You cannot conclude that Sam owns the radio from that.

The reason we are concluding that Sam owns the radio is based on the idea that an implication is false if A is true and B is false. If Sam is lying, and therefore if the implication "If I am 5 feet tall, then I own a ham radio" is false, then (according to pure logic) Sam must be 5 feet tall and he must not own a ham radio. However, from his first statement we know he must not be 5 feet tall. This creates a contradiction and so we know Sam is not lying. Therefore Sam is telling the truth, and so he has a ham radio.

Now, I don't really know if I like this logic, but it's what we're "supposed" to do.

This is a bit tricky because of the way formal logic treats conditionals: if the condition ppp is false, then "if ppp then qqq" is automatically true, never mind whether qqq is true or false.

So that his first statement is false, then his second statement is automatically true. Therefore Sam cannot be consistently lying today.

Both times he is speaking the truth. He is five feet tall, and therefore also has a ham radio.

So on any given day Sam either entirely tells the truth or lies. Given this we can predict what would happen in either scenario.

If Sam is completely telling the truth then the premise "I am exactly five feet tall" must be true so the if-then statement has to be true as well. The only way for a conditional to be true if the premise is true is for the conclusion to also be true.

However, if Sam is completely lying then the premise is false. But notice that if the premise of an if-then statement is false the statement is true no matter the truth value of the conclusion. Therefore we have a contradiction and so Sam could not have said these words on a day when he was completely lying.

In other words Sam must've been telling the truth on this day and so by our first argument Sam must own a ham radio.

Consider that Sam is telling the truth.

  • According to statement 1, he would be exactly five feet tall.

  • According to statement 2, he would own a ham radio since he is exactly five feet tall.

Consider that Sam is lying, then you can convert the two false statements back into true statements.

  • "I am exactly five feet tall." turns out to be "I am not exactly five feet tall."

  • The only statement that disproves the one declaring "If I am exactly five feet tall, then I also own a ham radio." is "I am exactly five feet tall, but I don't own a ham radio."

  • With that, we find out that the truth version of statement 1 says that Sam is five feet tall, but the one of statement 2 says that he isn't. There is a contradiction, so Sam can't be lying.

In conclusion, the only condition that can be true is that Sam is telling the truth, is exactly five feet tall and has a ham radio.

Chew-Seong Cheong

Today, Sam says:

  1. "I am exactly five feet tall."
  2. "If I am exactly five feet tall, then I also own a ham radio."

If Sam always tells the truth today, both the statements are true. That is he is exactly five feet tall. And since he is exactly five feet tall, yes he owns a ham radio.

If Sam always lies today, both the statements are false. That is he is not exactly five feet tall. Since the second statement is false, it means that the truth is either:

  • if he is exactly five feet tall, then he does not own a ham radio, but he is not exactly five feet tall, so yes he owns a ham radio;

or

  • if he is not exactly five feet tall, then he own a ham radio, since he is not exactly five feet tall, so yes he owns a ham radio.

So either he always tells the truth or always lies today, yes, he owns a ham radio.

For this problem, we would have only two cases, one in which Sam always tells the truth and one in which Sam always lies, as the behavior of Sam is not mentioned in the question.

First case-When Sam always tells the truth: If he says the truth, he would be exactly 5 feet tall and his statement "If I am exactly 5 feet tall, then I own a Ham radio" would also be true. As we have already established that he is 5 feet tall in this case, he will own a Ham radio.

Second case-When Sam always lies: If he lies, he would not be exactly five feet tall and his statement "If I am exactly 5 feet tall, then I own a Ham radio" would also be false, implying that if he is 5 feet tall, he will not have a Ham radio but if he is of any other height, he would possess a Ham radio. As we have already established that his height is not 5 feet, he would have a Ham radio.

In both the cases, we observe that Sam possesses a Ham radio. This concludes that whatever the behavior of Sam is on that day, he will surely possess a Ham radio.

Niko Nunez
Jul 31, 2020

Ok, so we have false days and we have true days, but let's first start with clarifying and structuring things so we do not get confused.

Sam is responsible for two conditions. He decides if this is the day he will lie and he decides upon the implication statement. This is what makes the problem tricky, because the implication statement is not decided upon by a third party. It is decided upon by the person within the problem.

If you are cautious you will notice Sam says the PREMISE (P), that he is exactly 5 ft tall, and the IMPLICATION (I), that if he is 5 ft tall he owns a HAM radio . He does not state the CONCLUSION (C) that he owns a HAM radio.

Sam says I am 5 feet tall (which is the Premise). He also says If I am 5 feet tall, I own a Ham radio (which is the implication).

On true days: P = True , C=not stated and I = True because remember everything Sam says is True on these days. So, the implication must be true. And when the premise is true the implication can only be true if the conclusion is true. Therefore Sam owns a HAM radio on true days

On false days: P=False, C=not stated and I=False because everything said by Sam on false days is a lie. But, the only way for I to be false is if P is true. This is not a breakdown in logic. It informs us that on days where Sam only lies, this true false game is impossible to play. He can only play it on days where he tells the truth.

Therefore Sam owns a Ham radio

Pierre-Henri Trivier
Jul 30, 2020

F : "I'm five feet tall"

R : "I have a radio"

(F => R) : "If I'm five feet tall, then I have a radio".

DT : "I always tell the true today"

DF: "I always lie today"

We have DT XOR DF.

I particular : Either both F & (F => R ) are true. Or *neither" F, nor (F => R) are true.

Now, using the equivalence (F => R) <=> (~F || R):

1
2
3
4
5
6
7
DT == True
<=> F & (F => R) == True
<=> F & (~F || R) == True
<=> (F & ~F) || (F & R) == True (by DeMorgan laws, I suppose)
<=> False || (F & R) == True
<=> True & R == True
<=> R == True

This case is possible, and implies that R is true.

However: 

1
2
3
4
5
6
7
8
DF == True
<=> ~F & ~(F => R) == True
<=> ~F & ~(~F || R) == True
<=> ~F & (~~F & ~R) == True (by DeMorgan laws, again)
<=> ~F & (F & ~R) == True
<=> (~F & F) & ~R == True
<=> False & ~R == True
<=> False == True

So:

1
2
3
4
(DF == True) xor (DR == True)
<=> (R == True) xor (False == True)
<=> (R == true) xor False
<=> (R == true)

Ron Schutjens

The reasoning of Gandoff Tan is correct. Look at his truth table like this (hope this notation makes it a bit easier).

  • A: I am 5ft tall
  • B: I have a ham radio
A==1B2
------------
TTT
TFF
FTT
FFT

You need to compare the possibilities of column A (which is statement 1 and the premise of the implication), and column 2 (which is statement 2 value), when you consider if Sam is ONLY telling the truth or lying.

The top row is the combination when he is ONLY telling the truth.

If Sam is ONLY lying, then both column A and column 2 have to be false. There is no combination where that is the case, so that situation will NEVER come up. So the statement in the paragraph above is the only possibility and thus Sam has a ham radio.

Please reread the explanation about when an implication is false, and don't post that you no nothing about the whether B is true or not if he is lying. Even if you think that this logic "doesn't make sense" this is how an implication works logically.

Another way of looking at it: when the premise is false, the truth of an implication doesn't depend on if the conclusion is false or not (regardless if you know anything about the conclusion).

Stewart Gordon
Jul 29, 2020

Solving using Boolean algebra. Let PPP be "I am exactly five feet tall" and QQQ be "I own a ham radio".

Suppose Sam is lying today. Then the combination of his statements, taken to be false, is ¬P∧¬(P⇒Q)\neg P \land \neg(P \Rightarrow Q)¬P∧¬(P⇒Q).

Suppose Sam is telling the truth today. Then the combination of his statements, taken to be true, is P∧(P⇒Q)P \land (P \Rightarrow Q)P∧(P⇒Q).

Sam's two statements are either both true or both false, giving us:

(¬P∧¬(P⇒Q))∨(P∧(P⇒Q))(\neg P \land \neg (P \Rightarrow Q)) \lor (P \land (P \Rightarrow Q))(¬P∧¬(P⇒Q))∨(P∧(P⇒Q))

Simplifying step by step:

(¬P∧¬(¬P∨Q))∨(P∧(¬P∨Q))(¬P∧P∧¬Q)∨(P∧(¬P∨Q))(⊥∧¬Q)∨(P∧(¬P∨Q))⊥∨(P∧(¬P∨Q))P∧(¬P∨Q)P∧(¬⊤∨Q)P∧(⊥∨Q)P∧Q(\neg P \land \neg (\neg P \lor Q)) \lor (P \land (\neg P \lor Q)) \\ (\neg P \land P \land \neg Q) \lor (P \land (\neg P \lor Q)) \\ (\bot \land \neg Q) \lor (P \land (\neg P \lor Q)) \\ \bot \lor (P \land (\neg P \lor Q)) \\ P \land (\neg P \lor Q) \\ P \land (\neg \top \lor Q) \\ P \land (\bot \lor Q) \\ P \land Q(¬P∧¬(¬P∨Q))∨(P∧(¬P∨Q))(¬P∧P∧¬Q)∨(P∧(¬P∨Q))(⊥∧¬Q)∨(P∧(¬P∨Q))⊥∨(P∧(¬P∨Q))P∧(¬P∨Q)P∧(¬⊤∨Q)P∧(⊥∨Q)P∧Q

showing that both "I am exactly five feet tall" and "I own a ham radio" are true.

Ralph Becket
Jul 28, 2020

Let p = "I am exactly five feet tall" and q = "I own a ham radio".

On truth days: p & (p => q) <=> q.

On false days: -p & -(p => q) <=> -p & (p & -q) <=> false

It must be a truth day (or we have a contradiction), hence Sam owns a ham radio.

Gordon Parks
Jul 28, 2020

At the start of the problem, there are three binary conditions which leads to eight possible states:

1Sam is telling the truthSam is exactly five feet tallSam own a ham radio
2Sam is telling the truthSam is exactly five feet tallSam doesn't own a ham radio
3Sam is telling the truthSam is not exactly five feet tallSam own a ham radio
4Sam is telling the truthSam is not exactly five feet tallSam doesn't own a ham radio
5Sam is not telling the truthSam is exactly five feet tallSam own a ham radio
6Sam is not telling the truthSam is exactly five feet tallSam doesn't own a ham radio
7Sam is not telling the truthSam is not exactly five feet tallSam own a ham radio
8Sam is not telling the truthSam is not exactly five feet tallSam doesn't own a ham radio

Then we begin analyzing his statements.

The first statement is relatively easy: Sam is either telling the truth and he is exactly five feet tall, or he's lying and not exactly five feet tall. Cases 3, 4, 5, and 6 all become paradoxical; the statement is either a lie when he must be telling the truth, or the statement is true when he must be lying. This leaves 1, 2, 7, or 8 as possible cases.

The second statement is more interesting. This statement is true any time Sam is exactly five feet tall and owns a ham radio. Case 2 is a paradox, since in that case the statement would have to be a lie when Sam has to be telling the true. The statement is also true any time Sam is not exactly five feet tall, regardless of whether he owns a ham radio or not. This eliminates case 7 and 8, since the statement would be true in those cases when he would have to be lying. ((Note: It also eliminates case 5, since the statement would again be true when he would have to be lying, but we already eliminated that earlier))

Of the original eight cases, the only one not eliminated is 1. Sam must be telling the truth, Sam is exactly five feet tall, and yes, he owns a ham radio.

Ranjith Chamala
Jul 27, 2020

First, we must assume that Sam is telling the truth. This implies that the initial statement is true. The second statement tells us that since the implication is true, the conclusion is also true. This means that Sam owns a ham radio.

Next, let's assume that Sam is lying. This means that he lied about being exactly 5 feet tall.

However, that means that he also lied when he said "If I am exactly 5 feet tall, then I also own a ham radio." This means that he can be a different height and still own a ham radio. Since we know he is lying about his height and he isn't exactly 5 feet tall, there is still a possibility that he owns a ham radio.

Since it is possible for Sam to own the ham radio regardless of whether he is telling the truth or lying, that is the answer.

Robert DeLisle
Jul 27, 2020

On the truth telling day, the conclusion is obvious, he owns the radio.

On the lying day. Sam is not exactly five feet tall because the first statement is false.

A->B is equivalent to ~B->~A. This is called the contra-positive of A->B.

The contra-positive of the second statement is:

"If I don't own a ham radio then I am not exactly five feet tall."

If Sam does NOT own a ham radio, this statement is true since he is not exactly five feet tall. Thus Sam's second statement would not be a lie on a day when all statements he makes are lies.

Therefore, Sam owns a ham radio.

Back when such puzzles (or problems as they were usually called) were presented in a math class or in a philosophy logic class, it always seemed a bit artificial. A clever real life liar would like to the intent of the questions rather than the logic class structure of the statements. This liar would be more like the joker in the knight, knave, joker puzzles than a pure liar.

Richard Desper
Jul 27, 2020

It is impossible for both the statements "A" and "A implies B" to be false. If "A" is false" then "A implies B" is true regardless of whether B is true or not.

Letting A = "I am exactly five feet tall" and B = "I own a ham radio", on the day in question Sam has said both "A" and "A implies B". Thus this cannot be a day when Sam lies about everything.

So it must be a truth-telling day and both statements are true.

And since both "A" and "A implies B" are true, it must be the case that "B" is also true. So Sam owns a ham radio.

Consider these two statements:

S1: Sam is a giraffe.

S2: If Sam is a giraffe, then Sam is a monkey.

Suppose S1 is false. S2 is obviously false (it's a contradiction). What does that say about Sam being a monkey (or not).

From Wikipedia:

"if Uluru is in France, then the Eiffel Tower is in Bolivia". Such statements are considered vacuous truths, because the fact that the antecedent is false prevents using the statement to infer anything about the truth value of the consequent (italics mine).

In this case the truth value of the consequent is indeterminable.

Interesting question that's made for a lively discussion, but the answer provided is not definitive.

@Brilliant Mathematics: what say you?

Dr. H
Jul 29, 2020
Upvote Upvoted 0
Resolved

I don't like this “challenge” and I believe the Brilliant squad got this one wrong.

As I see it, the “challenge” is muddled by the second proposition being a compound sentence

The first proposition is simple and evident. It's either true or false.

The second proposition, being a compound (or conditional) sentence, is neither true nor false. The famous example of a compound question in law (and I am not a lawyer, so excuse the generalities) is, “Do you only beat your spouse when you're drunk?” No matter how you answer, you will admit to beating your spouse. Compound questions are imprecise and assume facts not in evidence. That is precisely why compound questions are not admissible in court. But let's get back to mathematics.

In order to (hopefully) bring clarity to proposition 2, let's rephrase it. Take the Positive “If I am exactly 5 feet tall, then I also own a ham radio.” The logically equivalent statement is not the Inverse nor the Converse, but the Contrapositive. The Contrapositive statement is “If I also do not own a ham radio, then I am not exactly 5 feet tall.”

If you happen upon Sam on his truth telling days, then obviously Sam owns a ham radio. The logical imprecision comes on those days when Sam is lying about everything. On his lying days, proposition 1 is FALSE. We know that Sam is certainly not exactly 5 feet tall. Proposition 2 must also be FALSE on Sam's lying days. But what does a FALSE proposition 2 look like? Because proposition 2 is a compound statement, it's difficult to say. So Sam can own a ham radio and not be exactly 5 feet tall – giving the answer suggested by Brilliant. But suppose Sam, in reality, does not own a ham radio. Then the Contrapositive of proposition 2 would be TRUE, as Sam does not own a ham radio and is not exactly 5 feet tall. This is contrary to our conjecture that we caught Sam on a day on which Sam only lies.

In other words, on Sam's lying days, we do not know if he owns a ham radio or not. And I believe all of this imprecision stems from the compound nature of proposition 2.

An implication (also called an "if-then") is a statement in logic that connects two statements together in such a way that if the first is true, the second must also be true. For example, "If it is a dog, then it is a mammal" is an implication.
